title: How to Make a No‐Sew Ribbon Headband

steps.headline: Measure your head, then subtract 4 inches (10.16 centimeters).
steps.description:
Wrap a measuring tape around your head like a headband: under the back of your head, up the sides, and over the top of your head. Record your measurement, then subtract 4 inches (10.16 centimeters). This is your new measurement
If you don't have a measuring tape, you can use some ribbon or string instead, then use a ruler to subtract 4 inches (10.16 centimeters).

steps.headline: Cut your ribbon according to your new measurement.
steps.description: Choose a wider ribbon—something around 1 inch (2.54 centimeters) wide would be ideal. The ribbon can be satin or grosgrain. Satin comes in more colors, but grosgrain comes in more patterns.

steps.headline: Seal the ends of the ribbon with a flame.
steps.description: Light a candle or ignite a lighter. Hold the cut end of the ribbon close to the flame for a few seconds, or until the cut edge melts. Repeat for the other side.

steps.headline: Cut 4 inches (10.16 centimeters) of elastic.
steps.description: The elastic should be narrower than your ribbon. Something between ½ and ¾-inch (1.27 and 1.91-centimeter) wide would be ideal. If the elastic is super stretchy, you may want to cut it a little shorter to make the headband tighter.

steps.headline: Make a dot of hot glue on one end of the ribbon.
steps.description: Turn the ribbon so that the wrong side is facing you. Squeeze out a drop of hot glue on one end. Make sure that it's centered.

steps.headline: Press one end of the elastic into it.
steps.description: The end of the elastic needs to overlap the end of the ribbon by ½ inch (1.27 centimeters). Make sure that the elastic is centered.

steps.headline: Glue the side edges of the ribbon down onto the elastic.
steps.description: Make a small drop of hot glue on the ribbon to the left of the elastic. Fold the edge down onto the elastic and press it into place. Repeat for the right side.

steps.headline: Repeat the process for the other side of the ribbon.
steps.description: Place another drop of hot glue on the other end of the ribbon. Press the elastic into place, then glue the side edges down. You do not need to glue the side edges down along the entire ribbon—over the elastic.

steps.headline: Choose and cut your ribbon.
steps.description: You will need two 16-inch (40.64-centimeter) pieces of 1 inch (2.54-centimeter) wide ribbon. They can be the same color and pattern, or contrasting ones. Keep in mind that of the ribbons will be on the underside of your headband. Grosgrain ribbon is recommended for this project, but you can try other types as well.

steps.headline: Cut a shorter, narrower piece of Velcro.
steps.description: You will need one 15-inch (38.1-centimeter) piece of ¾-inch (1.91-centimeter) wide Velcro. Make sure that you are only using the hook part, and not the fuzzy part. For something softer, you could use velvet ribbon instead. It will offer some grip, but not as much. Black is the best choice because it doesn't show dirt as much.

steps.headline: Cut a short piece of elastic.
steps.description: You will need one 6-inch (15.24-centimeter) piece of ⅜-inch (0.95-centimeter) wide elastic. For a neater finish, match the elastic color to the Velcro color. Set the elastic aside for later.

steps.headline: Fold and glue the ends of the ribbons down by ½ inch (1.27 centimeters).
steps.description: Turn one of the ribbons so that the wrong side is facing you. Fold the left end down by ½-inch (1.27 centimeters), and secure it with a line of hot glue. Repeat for the other end, then for the other ribbon.

steps.headline: Glue the Velcro strip to one of the ribbons.
steps.description: Choose one of the ribbons to be the underside of your headband. Turn it so that the right side is facing you. Working 1 to 2 inches (2.54 to 5.08 centimeters) at a time, start hot gluing the Velcro to the ribbon. Make sure that it's centered.

steps.headline: Glue the ends of the elastic to the other ribbon.
steps.description: Turn the other ribbon over so that the wrong side is facing you. Make a drop of hot glue on one of the folded ends. Press the elastic into the glue, overlapping it by ½ inch (1.27 centimeters). Repeat for the other end.

steps.headline: Glue the ribbons together.
steps.description: Turn one of the ribbons so that the wrong side is facing you. Coat one end with hot glue, then press the other ribbon down into it, wrong-side-down. Continue gluing the two ribbons together, working a little bit at a time. Make sure that you extend the hot glue to the ends and edges.

steps.headline: Choose and cut your ribbon.
steps.description: Choose a piece of ribbon that is wide enough to cover your headband. Cut the ribbon so that it is about 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) longer than your headband. Grosgrain ribbon would work the best, but you can try other types as well.

steps.headline: Seal the ends of your ribbon.
steps.description: Light a candle or a lighter. Hold the end of your ribbon over the flame until the cut end melts and hardens. Repeat this step for the other end of the ribbon.

steps.headline: Start hot gluing the ribbon to the headband.
steps.description: Draw a squiggle of hot glue onto the headband, then quickly press the ribbon down into it. Leave about 1 inch (2.54 centimeters) of ribbon hanging over the end of the ribbon.

steps.headline: Continue hot gluing the ribbon to the headband.
steps.description: Work 1 to 2 inches (2.54 to 5.08 centimeters) at a time, or the hot glue will set too fast. Keep the ribbon straight and taut as you glue it down.

steps.headline: Taper the ends of the ribbon, if needed.
steps.description: Some headbands are wide at the center and narrow at the ends. If you have a headband like this, you'll need to fold the overhanging side edges under the headband, and hot glue them in place. Don't worry about the 1-inch (2.54-centimeter) bits of ribbon hanging over the ends just yet.

steps.headline: Fold and glue the ends of the ribbon.
steps.description: Cover one end of your headband with hot glue. Quickly fold the excess ribbon over the edge, and press it into the glue. Repeat this step for the other end of the headband.

steps.headline: Finished.

Making a Simple Headband Measure your head, then subtract 4 inches (10.16 centimeters). Wrap a measuring tape around your head like a headband: under the back of your head, up the sides, and over the top of your head. Record your measurement, then subtract 4 inches (10.16 centimeters). This is your new measurement
If you don't have a measuring tape, you can use some ribbon or string instead, then use a ruler to subtract 4 inches (10.16 centimeters). Cut your ribbon according to your new measurement. Choose a wider ribbon—something around 1 inch (2.54 centimeters) wide would be ideal. The ribbon can be satin or grosgrain. Satin comes in more colors, but grosgrain comes in more patterns. Seal the ends of the ribbon with a flame. Light a candle or ignite a lighter. Hold the cut end of the ribbon close to the flame for a few seconds, or until the cut edge melts. Repeat for the other side. Cut 4 inches (10.16 centimeters) of elastic. The elastic should be narrower than your ribbon. Something between ½ and ¾-inch (1.27 and 1.91-centimeter) wide would be ideal. If the elastic is super stretchy, you may want to cut it a little shorter to make the headband tighter. Make a dot of hot glue on one end of the ribbon. Turn the ribbon so that the wrong side is facing you. Squeeze out a drop of hot glue on one end. Make sure that it's centered. Press one end of the elastic into it. The end of the elastic needs to overlap the end of the ribbon by ½ inch (1.27 centimeters). Make sure that the elastic is centered. Glue the side edges of the ribbon down onto the elastic. Make a small drop of hot glue on the ribbon to the left of the elastic. Fold the edge down onto the elastic and press it into place. Repeat for the right side. Repeat the process for the other side of the ribbon. Place another drop of hot glue on the other end of the ribbon. Press the elastic into place, then glue the side edges down. You do not need to glue the side edges down along the entire ribbon—over the elastic. Making a No-Slip Headband Choose and cut your ribbon. You will need two 16-inch (40.64-centimeter) pieces of 1 inch (2.54-centimeter) wide ribbon. They can be the same color and pattern, or contrasting ones. Keep in mind that of the ribbons will be on the underside of your headband. Grosgrain ribbon is recommended for this project, but you can try other types as well. Cut a shorter, narrower piece of Velcro. You will need one 15-inch (38.1-centimeter) piece of ¾-inch (1.91-centimeter) wide Velcro. Make sure that you are only using the hook part, and not the fuzzy part. For something softer, you could use velvet ribbon instead. It will offer some grip, but not as much. Black is the best choice because it doesn't show dirt as much. Cut a short piece of elastic. You will need one 6-inch (15.24-centimeter) piece of ⅜-inch (0.95-centimeter) wide elastic. For a neater finish, match the elastic color to the Velcro color. Set the elastic aside for later. Fold and glue the ends of the ribbons down by ½ inch (1.27 centimeters). Turn one of the ribbons so that the wrong side is facing you. Fold the left end down by ½-inch (1.27 centimeters), and secure it with a line of hot glue. Repeat for the other end, then for the other ribbon. Glue the Velcro strip to one of the ribbons. Choose one of the ribbons to be the underside of your headband. Turn it so that the right side is facing you. Working 1 to 2 inches (2.54 to 5.08 centimeters) at a time, start hot gluing the Velcro to the ribbon. Make sure that it's centered. Glue the ends of the elastic to the other ribbon. Turn the other ribbon over so that the wrong side is facing you. Make a drop of hot glue on one of the folded ends. Press the elastic into the glue, overlapping it by ½ inch (1.27 centimeters). Repeat for the other end. Glue the ribbons together. Turn one of the ribbons so that the wrong side is facing you. Coat one end with hot glue, then press the other ribbon down into it, wrong-side-down. Continue gluing the two ribbons together, working a little bit at a time. Make sure that you extend the hot glue to the ends and edges. Making a Ribbon Covered Headband Choose and cut your ribbon. Choose a piece of ribbon that is wide enough to cover your headband. Cut the ribbon so that it is about 2 inches (5.08 centimeters) longer than your headband. Grosgrain ribbon would work the best, but you can try other types as well. Seal the ends of your ribbon. Light a candle or a lighter. Hold the end of your ribbon over the flame until the cut end melts and hardens. Repeat this step for the other end of the ribbon. Start hot gluing the ribbon to the headband. Draw a squiggle of hot glue onto the headband, then quickly press the ribbon down into it. Leave about 1 inch (2.54 centimeters) of ribbon hanging over the end of the ribbon. Continue hot gluing the ribbon to the headband. Work 1 to 2 inches (2.54 to 5.08 centimeters) at a time, or the hot glue will set too fast. Keep the ribbon straight and taut as you glue it down. Taper the ends of the ribbon, if needed. Some headbands are wide at the center and narrow at the ends. If you have a headband like this, you'll need to fold the overhanging side edges under the headband, and hot glue them in place. Don't worry about the 1-inch (2.54-centimeter) bits of ribbon hanging over the ends just yet. Fold and glue the ends of the ribbon. Cover one end of your headband with hot glue. Quickly fold the excess ribbon over the edge, and press it into the glue. Repeat this step for the other end of the headband. Finished.
